Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Multi-Material 3D Printer to Enable Novel Multi-disciplinary Research and Research Training

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant provides funding for the acquisition of a high resolution, multi-material 3D printer at Union College. By harnessing a huge demand for prototyping technologies, researchers will launch a new era of innovative research, with applications ranging from the neuromechanics of dragonfly capture to the manufacture of novel aerogel coated surfaces to the design of completely soft robots. This will bridge the growing rapid prototyping "knowledge gap" in higher education. The accelerated development cycles facilitated by modern rapid prototyping will enable researchers to continuously iterate and improve upon designs, "failing cheaply and quickly" before arriving at novel and sometimes unexpected solutions. Students across multiple disciplines experienced with the benefits of rapid prototyping will find their services increasingly in demand by employers in coming years.

This 3D printer will be at the center of an inherently cross-disciplinary and highly collaborative research program at Union College. Providing a common space in which community members can design solutions and solve problems together will help foster and spark spontaneous interdisciplinary collaborations. Students using the space will be emboldened as craftspersons and enabled as entrepreneurs. Educators at the college will be able to design novel interactive models and demonstrations. Not only will this acquisition help set the standard for the integration of rapid prototyping techniques into undergraduate research and teaching, it will provide tools, methods, and environments around which tomorrow's designers will coalesce and thrive. This program will continue Union College's strong record of undergraduate research among students from traditionally underrepresented groups, through programs such as the Science and Technology Entry Program (STEP), designed to prepare historically underrepresented students for the sciences, and the POSSE program, designed to identify students with leadership potential and strong academics who might be overlooked in the traditional college selection process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acquisition of this high resolution Multi-Material 3D printer enabled a wide variety of Multi-disciplinary Research and Research training at Union College.  The Union Collaborative Design Studio (UCDS), built to house the printer, became a hub of interdisciplinary scientific collaboration.  

The intellectual contributions of this work range from new types of soft robot to new understanding of moss ecosystems.  Professor John Rieffel (Computer Science) used the printer to fabricate novel soft robots that had been automatically designed using innovative artifiical intelligence techniques.  Professor  Ann Anderson (Mechanical Engineering) and students printed small boat hulls that were used to investigate the drag reducing characteristics of surfaces coated with hydrophobic aerogels.  Professor Kirkton (Biology) printed custom-fit "saddles" for grasshoppers, to measure the effects of weight change on hopping performance.  Priofessor Olberg (Neuroscience) printed small eyepatches to selectively cover the eyes of dragonflies in his investigation of flight neuroethology.   Professor Steve Rice (Biology) and his students printed detailed models of moss canopies in order to study their carbon integration and water dynamics.  Professor Mike Hagerman (Chemistry) used the printer to prototype water nanoparticle-based filter designs for removal of E. coli from contaminated water samples.  Professor Theodosiu  (Biology) used the device to print detailed models of developing skate intestines imaged on Union's micro-CT scanner.

The printer was also used for a wide range of student-driven research projects and capstone theses.  Mechanical engineering students designed flexible prosthetics for child amputees.  Computer engineers designed and printed flexible robotic hands.  Electrical engineering students designed artificial voice boxes.

More broadly, thanks to this initial acquisition Union College  developed a vibrant "Maker" culture -- growing their fabrication ecosystem to include smaller 3D printers, laser cutters, 3D laser scanners and even sewing machines.  The 3D printing skills and tools acquired by students have been used not just by students in STEM, but also by professors and students in English Literature, Russian, and Theater.  Our library has also used the printer to produce replicas of historical artifacts in the college's permanent collection.
